comments.commentBody: Morning, Great job as always. Appreciate your good work, also the gun report, you have you finger on the pulse of corruption in the capital of corruption - NYC.

I would make this modest suggestion: if the loan to Mr. Silverstein is approved to build a building for which there is no practical use, then one day a week, every single week until that building is finished, drivers who already pay the outrageous tolls for the city's bridges and tunnels drive through without paying the toll. Every single person. Leave your EZ Passes at home on that day, don't remove a dollar from your wallet. Keep every ticket you're issued, photocopy it, once for the Port Authority, once for Mr. Silverstein, and once for the public record. If it's a crossing with gates just stop until they are lifted. Let the traffic back up to Pennsylvania, Montauk, Maine. There is a time for action, and it looks as though that time may surely be coming.

Mary Scott Medvedev did not intervene in Georgia. He was on vacation on a
cruise ship when the invasion took place. Prime Minister Putin was left in
charge. No wonder no one trust Putin. Putin then had a rubber stamp Duma that changed the law so now he can stay in power for about 7 years each term.

Perhaps, Crimeans should have looked to South Ossetia, which Russia formally recognized as independent of Georgia in 2008, before voting.

Russian promises to repair homes and buildings damaged when Georgia attacked to prevent their secession are largely unfixed. Unemployment and prices for needed goods are high. Distribution of Russian funds have been riddled with corruption.

What's most interesting is that Medevev's popularity at home soared when he intervened in Georgia, just as Putin's has with annexing Crimea.

It's no wonder Putin continues to press ahead in unraveling Ukraine. That seems to be the kind of behavior his constituents, in large numbers, seem to favor.

http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/19/world/europe/south-ossetia-crimea.html
The return is not easy anymore. "Calling to separatism" is now a criminal offence in Russia and hence in Crimea.

Hard to feel too badly for the Crimeans, most of whom welcomed the "maskiyas" and stormtroopers by sticking flowers in their guns and then, except for the Tatars and a few folks who still considered themselves "Ukrainians", voted in a Stalinite plebiscite with 94% approval.

I don't wish this on anyone but then these people wished this on themselves and now have buyer's remorse. Unfortunately, it's a little hard to "return" a country when you've become dissatisfied with your "purchase", especially when you have charming Russian bureaucrats running the "return desk."

Donetsk and Kharkiv, pay close attention, very close attention.
What has made them so gullible?  Ignorance!

Lee, I share your outrage at Ms. McCarthy's pseudo science. I contracted measles when I was three years old and was very sick for two months. My doctor and parents were terrified that my eyesight would be compromise. Luckily that was not the case but my mother insisted that I wear sunglasses from that point on. My parents were thrilled when the measles vaccine was developed and had my younger siblings protected against this disease.
I think that our country has been dumbed down for the last twenty years.(Read Idiot America by Charles Pierce). People who believe that Earth is 6000 years old and that men rode dinosaurs are treated with the same respect as people who believe in evolution. Education is disparaged: Scott Brown used to call Elizabeth Warren "Professor" in their debates as if this was something to be ashamed of. We have reached a time here where everyone's an expert, and if everyone's an expert no one is an expert.
I too suffer from hearing loss from measles. I try to explain this to my young cousin who is anti-vaccine.  I can't get through to her.

I want this misguided and dangerous woman to meet all of us who have life-long disabilities from measles contracted before there was a measles vaccination. I want her to meet the parents whose vivacious children prior to contracting measles ended up needing life-long care because of permanent brain damage. I want her to meet the children who had perfect hearing and lost it from the high fever brought on by measles (I am one of those children) or those whose eyesight was fine prior to becoming ill. I want her to understand just how selfish this stance is. And to all the people who believe her pseudo-science, I want to ask them just what has made them so gullible?

"The unelected political operatives ... attach themselves to elected politicians, much like leeches, and suck every last bit of humanity and moral commitment from the actual office holders."

Yes, yes, and these operatives replace what they've sucked with air-time, publicity, speaking points and money, so the 'victim' doesn't actually look or sound or smell like the Zombie he or she's become. 'Tis a sad state we're in, yes, but there IS a cure for Zombi-nation...

And that's the voting machine, consistently and thoroughly applied to each and every suppurating wound on the body politick. Please note that treatment time for Zombies rolls round again in six short months. Plan accordingly.

Bravo! This is exactly one of the major problems of modern "democratic" government is.

The unelected political operatives (I almost said "opportunists") who attach themselves to elected politicians, much like leeches, and suck every last bit of humanity and moral commitment from the actual office holders. We are not governed by the people we actually elect, but by these "professional advisors".

It has always amazed me, how FORMER Presidents, and FORMER politicians in general, actually start to sound like real living, breathing human beings once out of office, with good ideas and obvious convictions (OK, Chaney is the exception which proves the rule). While in office they seem more like robots, programmed by their "handlers", their heads stuffed full of "position papers" and polling data, never taking and maintaining a discernible position on any issue.

From the minute someone is elected into any office, she/he is in re-election mode. The only way around that which I can come up with is to make high level elected positions (such as President) single term, say six years. We cannot afford to have wishy-washy Presidents for four years, in the hope that during the final term he will actually have the courage of his convictions.
Antoher invasion by whom? the US who managed Iraq and afghanisthan? Horrors.

The Scottish referendum is being run with the blessing of the UK government in London. And the referendum movement has been brewing for years and the election is still months away.

It isn't being held at gun point while a foreign military stands guard ensuring that the people vote the way the people with the guns want them to.

To compare the two is like comparing a banana to an elephant.
in Crimea there are no problems, the article are exaggerated. Russia increased social pensions and zaplatili happy.

Once the nationalistic fervor subsided, Crimea’s world has turned upside down. Simplest of tasks have become a bureaucratic quagmire; purchases of daily necessities has become a choir; and Crimea where life was once pretty well-organized and smooth, is gone! The Ukrainian language, school curriculum, church and its priests are under siege, fascistic acts done on Russian territory against a Ukrainian minority. The move to annex Crimea was made with no regard to its native population. To the Russians on the mainland; it was a cause for celebration; for native Crimean’s a time for alarm and uncertainty.  To paraphrase Ronald Reagan, to the people of Crimea ask yourselves” are you better off now than 1 month ago?” With Putin’s annexation and the hardships it created in Crimea, will another invasion be necessary to avert attention from the problems in Crimea?

Russians make 52% of population in Crimea. Less of half of that thought about "unity" with Russia. It's 20-25% of entire population, mostly with soviet mentality. Those people didn't have loyalty to their home. Ukraine gave them education, gave them jobs, paid their social benefits, 90% of tourism was from Ukraine...
500 Russian schools and only 5 Ukrainian....
They could travel freely to Russia and see for themselves how life there is like, or move to Russia for good, if they felt there would be better life for them there...
It doesn't matter what promises Putin made, it doesn't matter that he made tons of same promises in occupied Abkhazia and Ossetia 6 years ago - and there is nothing there ever since but barbed wire, and Crimeans didn't know about that ---- people in every country feel slighted by their governments, complain about conditions every day --- but they don't invite foreign invasion to their country. This is what is called loyalty, patriotism - something those Crimeans did not have.
Ukraine is going to be to Russia what Iraq was to the US.  Like the old Roach Motel commercials said, "Roaches check in, but they don't check out!"

There are loads of credible studies showing that autism actually develops way earlier (now, even a study showing there are signs in the womb), it's just that obvious recognition of signs to the parents happens around the age of vaccination. You were probably hyper vigilant after the shots given the atmosphere and simply picked up on something that had been very slowly developing for a while. The problem, of course, is timing. Vaccination and recognition of symptoms of autism tend to temporally correspond, but not because one causes the other. Most girls start their periods in middle school; it doesn't mean middle school causes periods.

You should not feel guilty. Your son may have autism, but he didn't get brain damage, or permanent disabilities, or die from a preventable disease. You did the right thing. The best thing for your son and everyone else on the autism spectrum now is to use the limited research money set aside for autism to study real potential causes and cures. Continuing to reprove that vaccines do not cause autism over and over and over does nobody any good.

While I would never take Ms. McCarthy as an expert on anything more than bare skin and self-promotion, I must admit that our now 14-year-old Aspergers son WAS a smiley, talkative, outgoing baby. (We have the video tapes.) It would take a couple of hours to grab groceries because grandmas, moms, teenage girls, checkers, and even middle-age men were somehow drawn to him.

Within 72 hours of his first set of vaccinations, he was a different little guy. The smile, "talking" and light seemed to leave him. (Again, we have the video tapes.)

BTW-the reason we waited for his first vaccinations until he crawling was because his older sister had bad reactions to her shot schedule.

I just don't know...

(I often wonder if Autism/Asperger kids are the natural evolution of humankind: linear, logical, pedantic, seemingly not interested in social interaction. Seems like the perfect human for the future of computer interaction/implantation.)

I like what you say about 'tolls are nothing but taxes'.

That pretty much sums up what it feels like to be a voter these days, if you don't pay (for your candidate to compete) your vote essentially doesn't count.

Its a poll tax by another name. (Apologies for being off-topic)

Tolls SHOULD be used to manage the volume of traffic in and through the city. It is not outrageous that they are collected or high. It is outrageous that the revenue is not used to develop public transportation alternatives.
Take a ride on the "riff raft".

The Port Authority's ability to go overboard rests on the tolls paid by New Yorkers. Limit or eliminate some the tolls and the problem of overreach goes away.

The so called EZ-Pass paved the way for repeated toll increases. It should be called EZ-Pay or Quick Access (to your wallet). Because people zip through the tolls without having to pull out the cash, the price increases have occurred at a rapid rate since the introduction of the system. (I don't have the full figures, but I know the tolls now are considerably higher than they were in the past.)

As a frequent visitor with family throughout New York, I pondered for years why citizens put up with paying taxes every time they want to go somewhere. (Tolls are nothing but taxes, paid on the spot.) A partial answer dawned on me: the tolls act as inhibitors of free movement. People in the various jurisdictions don't want others coming their way. (Even the "public parks" on Long Island are private.) They want you to stay put. If they pay big bucks to live someplace, they don't want "riff raft" having easy access to it. They want exclusion.

A secondary effect of tolls is to make it more difficult for people to find work outside of where they live. Of course, there is the subway, but that doesn't serve every place, all the time. An unemployed person, low on funds, isn't going to search as far and wide as otherwise.

A trip to and from the DC area to NYC now costs more than 60 dollars in tolls.

http://terryreport.com
Mr. Brooks, you got it right this time!

How is this supposed to be so sophisticated? How is this supposed to be the 21st century cyber warfare? Because the Russian commanders have computers there?

No, this isn't new at all. This is just the 2014 version of Hitler's campaign before the outbreak of war in Europe. This is the same old tactic used by every 2 bit dictator since the beginning of time.

Why is Michael Gordon impressed that the Russian troops had no insignias. Was anyone ever fooled that they were not Russians? I do not see how this is something new and great. I believe all of this Putin adventure is just another sad and pathetic attempt to succeed where every other dictator has failed.

Putin cannot succeed. In broad and general terms, Putin does not have God on his side.
Seems to be about as significant a show of strength as America's invasion of Grenada.

Chris M
As a person, spaeaking about Russian law, you must know, that you can perfectly open bank accounts, register cars and register children in school with a Ukrainian (as well as Belarus, Kazakh, etc) domestic passport. And there are about 3 million ukraininan citizens living and working in Russia. Their salaries make about 20% of Ukraine's GDP.
Regardless of who's side your on, what is evident is that Crimeans are having "buyer's remorse".

Anton Yakovlev,

Even I was able to open a bank account in Moscow using my US passport.

But you miss the larger point. The people in Crimea are no longer Ukrainian citizens. Their national passports are no longer valid as they would no longer be recognized by the Ukrainian government, I would think.

More importantly, as the people in Crimea are now Russian citizens, why should they open bank accounts in banks next to their homes as foreign citizens, which is what they would be doing by using their Ukrainian documents?

The people are no longer considered Ukrainian citizens so they need Russian documents. And, as a Russian living in Sochi, you surely know the importance of having such documentation.

You show these pictures as a symbol of decadence , chaos and loss of control . As a symbol of suffering. However, you are fundamentally wrong. Think about it , yesterday you said that Russia Crimea not support that there vote at gunpoint , that there is no one wants to Russia , and now you show queue for a passport and citizenship. In your they all gathered there by force or from despair ? What you will be tomorrow? It's not Putin took the Crimea . This Crimeans raised on the shoulders of the Crimea , and fled with him to Russia . And they , and citizens in the south and east of the country in '23 said that they were second-class citizens . They were abused , they were told what language they should speak and think , what songs to sing, what people consider their heroes. '23 They worked to earn money, and then they took away the money and gave the western regions of the country .
Actually no one in the Crimea and nothing else did not expect . Try to do everything faster. There's more than 2 million people and thousands of businesses and organizations , tens of thousands of points necessary to provide and implement . Replacement forms, seals . Daylight notaries, courts, the police , the Legislature and other authorities on the Russian laws and the rule of law .

If you think people of Crimea were better off under Ukraine than they are now, with a stronger coin, better pensions and salaries and the protection of thir kin, then you are all ignorant. May I remind you that Ukraine is shooting against it's own people in it's eastern regions (wait, I forgot they are not people, they are "thugs", at least by Us double standard of freedom and democracy). If all Crimea has to pay for it's new status is a bit of uncertainty (which is to be expected given the situation, I BELIEVE) and a closed McDonald's or two, I don't think anybody there will scream to go back to Ukraine. Where, by the way, people are paying gas 40 per cent more than before the "liberation" (from an elected president, that is) and are going to be flooded by taxes in order to pay new debts to the Ifm. I suspect the opposite will happen in a couple of months...

I agree. He knows how to act the leader, but the rot of Russian life for the ordinary citizen, especially out of the cities, is beyond his interest. It's sad how life there is still mired in the Soviet mindset and most Russians can't shake it.

Hate to say "told you so" on the aftermath of this. But...

Said it before, will say it again - We'll see how happy all the Russians in Ukraine are when they are part of Russia. Putin talks and acts one way, but I don't think he knows how to run a country.

Windows 8 user on a Samsung laptop. I had the HTML error in my AcrossLite also. With the first clue where it appeared being "Whoops" I definitely thought it was part of the clue. Then I kept seeing the error and thought it was part of the theme. I could not figure out the connection to TICK TOCK so I came to the blog and then checked the PDF to see if it was just a coding error. Seems that it was.

Funny that this puzzle has an Eartha KITT, a feline CAT, and a Kit KAT. Tasty. Sometimes I guess a constructor feels like a NUTCASE; sometimes they DOTE.

edward.  To add I don't really care if someone who absolutely, no doubt did what these two guys are charged with suffer a bit in their execution.  But I oppose the death penalty because innocent people are executed or subject to execution.  Not a lot are innocent but even if one happens it's one too many.  There has just been too many false prosecutions and poor investigations to support the death penalty anymore.

Well said. A significant percentage of the population has first hand experience that people can be easily and painlessly sedated to a state of unconsiousness. At this point there are several ways in which the execution can be completed. Ironically, anyone with medical knowledge is aware that it takes highly trained, skilled professionals to make sure that you DO NOT expire under deep sedation.

Let us say for the sake of argument that the GOP are right about the poor ie that they are simply 'flawed' human beings; how do these flaws render the poor unworthy of our help? If the flaws are to some degree genetic, how are they responsible for that? If the flaws are the result of the social and economic conditions they grow up in, how are they responsible for that? If like me you think in Buddhist terms, and see the poor's plight as a combination of all the above, AND the underlying karmic forces in their lives, again, how are the poor not worthy of our empathy and succour?

Further, even if by some cosmic anomaly none of the above pertains to why a particular individual is an unemployed drug addict on social assistance, clearly the individual is suffering, and this suffering, whatever its root cause, is something to mourn. In that individual's suffering is the whole of our species' tragic history, and is a momentous thing, which the Buddha identified so perspicaciously as duhkha, the pillar of the Four Noble Truths.

In the New Testament, Jesus acts boldly to alleviate the suffering of the poor, particularly in the few places that the more rigorous biblical scholars suggest the historical Jesus can be heard to speak. Jesus is not interested in assigning blame, as he knows that is not a path of the heart. The path he chose was meant to teach us that pain and its humiliation are transcendent, that the poor are us learning that which we must if we are to evolve.
Stop buying cigarettes, booze, lottery tickets, cell phones, satellite TV and the savings add up.

Can you provide a list of goods that people are allowed to own while still being considered poor?  May they have any teeth?  Can they have shoes?  May they have a winter coat?  May they have a telephone?  Can they own a car?  Can they own land?  What goods do you consider to be the ones that catapult people out of poverty?

To Nigel: you seem to have a lot of free time, with all your comments. Why don't you come on down here and put yourself to work packing food bags for kids on Fridays, or volunteering to build the community center, or taking some disabled person shopping or an elder to their doctor's appointment, or teaching like many of us do. I'm a college professor in Cabel county. Sure, it's long hours and low pay, but its worth it as some of these kids actually do succeed. They are bright and ambitious, and maybe they could learn a lot from someone so wise as you.

There's no problem with readers' knowing the details of the charges of conviction, although it's likely that the vast majority of people reading an article like this are already well aware that defendants are sentenced to death upon conviction for murder only when particularly aggravated circumstances are proved. And contrary to ZAW's claim, this article •does• state the nature of the crimes the condemned were convicted of:

"Mr. Lockett received the death penalty for the 1999 kidnapping, rape and murder of a 19-year-old woman and Mr. Warner for the 1997 murder and rape of an 11-month-old girl."

It's also true, however, that the particular criminal acts these men, or any other defendants, were convicted of, have •no• bearing on the merits of their claims. They could be the most heinous criminals ever; in our system of justice, they have an absolute right not to be tortured to death. Accordingly, they have a right to relevant information, such as the source and nature of the drugs the state intends to use to kill them, that's necessary for a court to make a reasoned assessment of their claims.

In that regard, ZAW is simply wrong: not only is the nature of their crimes not •important• in this matter, it's simply irrelevant to the legal question at issue. And, by the way, even if drug manufacturers might be subject to "intimidation and threats" (by no means an established fact), that, too, simply does not negate the legal rights of the condemned.

— Brian

Like many anti-death penalty articles, this one misses two important facts.
.
First, the reason states are secretive about their sources for execution drugs, is to protect the manufacturers from intimidation and threats. Were it not for these threats, this would be a non issue.
.
Second and more importantly, it let's readers remain ignorant of the crimes that these two men committed. Allow me to fix that. Clayton Lockett shot 19 year old Stephanie Nieman with a sawed off shotgun. He then watched as accomplices buried the girl alive. Charles Warner brutally raped, and killed, the 11 month old daughter of his live in girlfriend.
.
Death penalty foes like to leave off these details. Maybe it's too painful to think about. Maybe it makes it harder to cast aside any sort of emotion or empathy and think purely on cold, legal terms. But to ignore the bloody details is to miss half the story. It does a real disservice to the people making anti-death penalty arguments, and it's a slap in the face to the victims in these cases.

No one forces any of us to believe what we read or hear.  Even when it's coming from someone in the public eye.  And that's especially true regarding views about something as serious as Autism and avoiding vaccinations being pushed by someone who is not a health professional or an expert.  Perhaps that's the most important lesson to be gleaned from this unfortunate siituation.
